Wow is this a bland and boring game. It might be the worst game I have ever played that isn't targeted at children.
Ignore the military robots, it's mostly just resource extraction. I guess maybe you fight once just to get some points.

I don't like that the "bottom-row actions" on the player boards become useless in the later part of the game. For example when you have built all your buildings, the build action is then pointless. Unfortunately this is true for ALL the bottom-row actions. Why can you do less after you developed your faction? This aspect of gameplay is highly unsatisfying for me. I will have to play the game a couple more times to see if this really bothers me.

Yes, you can keep using the bottom-row actions just for the money / bonuses, but they cost the same as if using them fully, which makes no sense: "So I use a build action paying materials required to build a building that I do not build. And then I get money."
This could be solved simply by "unlocking" some special ability or bonus when completing a bottom-row action.

I also don't like the game's combat system which I find too deterministic and boring.

Also the replayability of this game is pretty low, since there is no variability in setup and faction abilities. The only thing different from game to game are the Encounter Cards, so you may get different resources each game, which won't alter the gameplay significantly.

Update: It was discovered that several faction/player mat combinations are severely overpowered (Crimea/Patriotic and Rusviet/Industrial). These combinations are now officially banned from play. I think insufficient playtesting is a general problem in the industry that needs to be addressed (see also Fantasy Flight Games). Infuriatingly, the designer Jamey Stegmaier announced the broken factions will not be fixed, so I consider this game broken until he changes his mind.

Decisions were too obvious, too simple, and repetitive. Make resources, buy stuff, repeat. Game drags. Too long. Speeding up play by doing your bottom row action while opponent starts their turn didn't work either. The first thing my opponent said when I tried to speed up the game this way, was "I'll wait. I want to see what you're doing." There was only one time where I had to think twice about something and that was a rare attack situation. Otherwise, we're playing solitaire.

I did not like how easy it was to accumulate combat cards when you got the enlist actions going, especially considering that battles are very infrequent. I had 9 cards in hand at one point. What's the point? And your opponent getting benefit when you used the enlist action was too hard to keep track of and made zero thematic sense. Could drop this part and it would make little difference. Also seemed a waste to have only max one or two objective cards available when there is a full deck of them. There should have been more access to this, and less to getting extra combat cards.

Too easy to get around the map with tunnel access everywhere, mines, extra speed. Keeping track of your opponents movement options also a chore as each faction is different. Not much interaction, and battles are a crapshoot as you just get lucky when drawing combat cards. Could easily get a 5 or a 2. No skill involved there.

My advice for future designers: find a good painting, then kickstart a game based on it. You too can raise 1.8 million. The box art is amazing, only wish the game was half as good.

Update: rating lowered from 5 to a 1. Not impressed with Stegmaier's attitude and customer service. Refused to replace damaged parts of the game, even after sending photos. Or you could use your goods. But wait, you cant because you just took that action, or worse, its a coin action and mind you, coins are VP.

I love the action selection mechanism here (top/bottom) and how it can vary from game to game, faction to faction, which can radically change your approach to strategizing right out of the gate. The gate itself, though, tends to feel anticlimactic at times, especially toward the end. I think it has something to do with the endgame trigger(s), which can come on rather quickly and without much resistance if players aren't actively trying to impede others. It is perfectly conceivable that everyone stays isolated "doing their own thing" in separate partitions of the map, trying to race to six stars before everyone else. This game is far less exciting than the one that has people constantly battling and vying for the most resource rich spots on the map. The issue is that I'm not sure the game itself does enough to incentivize interaction.

I played this once a long time ago. I cannot believe somebody saw *that* art of *those* mechs and then made *this* game. The theme isn’t “pasted on”; the theme and the game literally have nothing to do with one another. Wrapping this game in that art is wasting a cool theme. This, rather than the not-terribly-interesting gameplay, is the reason I will never play Scythe again - it’s worse than false advertising, it’s almost a dog in the manger move on the art.

Side note, Stegmaier games always leave me cold (apart from charterstone). They aren’t intricate enough as Euros to excite me with gameplay, and they never integrate the theme at all well. The fact they’re really derivative to boot makes me feel like I should just play whatever he was inspired by.

Oh fanboy, please spare me your paean for the umpteenth marketing darling: no matter what wonders you keep spinning about it, Scythe still is just a dry euro wrapped in a shiny plating, and no character of its own.

And I don’t care what you say about the mediocre components (just a handful of wooden bits and some 3d printed mechs) nor the illustrations either, that look nice at first but soon you can’t but notice they lack character, they’re all the same and suggest a kind of game Scythe is not, by far.
Despite the illustrations, Scythe is not a wargame and combats only count for a minimal fraction of the game: they’re more of a requisite to meet once or twice than the core mechanism. You fight because you have to, in a very bureaucratic way: to match victory conditions and earn points, not to annihilate your opponents. No dice, no randomness, no suspense: where’s the thrill of a simulated combat and the joy of winning it out of mere luck when you can take everything of its outcome into account?
You can’t even divert too much attention from grinding resources into fighting since combat earns you nothing but is more likely to cost you something when you win. And that’s just laughable, comparable in its nonsense to the comical «join a fight just to lose it on purpose» mechanism in Blood Rage: pointless.

That is because Scythe is first and foremost an optimization engine, a cube pusher by the book.
Hence, unsurprisingly, it’s all about learning how to navigate your player board; and, equally unsurprisingly, managing said board is fiddly and requires constant thinking and planning, so you always have to settle for a mediocre action that doesn’t quench your thirst for resources.
So, while you’re deciding what to do next and where to move that «upgrade» cube, you don’t have any time to interact with the other players, you don’t even notice what they’re doing as you struggle with the actions you’d wish to take but cannot because you’re always short on options.

And the theme you’re boasting about...it’s as thin as air in a cold winter morning: maybe enough for the typical control freaks that get excited for a game like this but lacking for everyone else who’s worth his weight in dice.
Theme is more than just suggestive art pieces and a twinkly setting with no real effects on the game.
Theme is a rich lore, appropriate special rules that come along once in a while, matching your actions with a feeling of what you’re pretending to do: theme means character, an identity of its own.
It’s more than just a cute illustration and three options on an encounter card, the most «thematic» thing in the game: theme would rather require a suitable title, a short introduction to the scene, some lore maybe, and different, unpredictable rewards that don’t all feel the same, with comparable gains and losses over each card, but vary appropriately and might even be worse than expected.

No, there’s nothing to salvage in Scythe: it’s the poster boy of a soulless game, and it even sucks at it.
A thousand ways to score, not one of them interesting.

The art is neat, the mechanics seem interesting at first glance before realizing it's the most safe, baby-proofed design I can imagine (make a chain of possible actions, except said chain is entirely self-contained and immutable), then let players pick 1 of 3 of them (technically 1 of 4, but you can't generally pick the same action two turns in a row),

Stonemeier Games is the Silversun Pickups of Boardgames: it’ll get you through the day but their output only reminds you of much better artists doing similar work. Viticulture, Wingspan, Charterstone, and this sad fake war game all come off as reskins of better WPs, engine builders, legacy games, and pseudo-war games. Sure, they’re purdy, but they’re empty calories. The actual mechanics of Scythe only guarantee a dull cold war and a plodding engine for your empire. You’re buying it for minis and art, and that is everything that is wrong with the current state of this fucking industry. Play better games. Support better companies.

TL;DR - Scythe is not the Second Coming, and certainly not one of the Top 100 game of all time, let alone Top 10.
low replayability, have a feeling that you are playing the game on your own player board, some factions are clearly better than other, weird interaction between players

Classic Stegmaier game; lots of 'win more', an overly convoluted scoring system and an anticlimactic end. Ameritrash at its finest if playing this kind of game is what you're into. And don't let it's 'engine building' fool you, it's only the illusion of choice here trying to masquerade as a more complex Euro type game. Tiny wooden pieces does not a Euro make. I don't think it's fun, players rarely interacted and it was like playing spreadsheet the board game.

I can see why people love this game, but it’s not for me. It’s well-designed, gorgeous, and intricate. However, I’m completely over it and never want to play it again after the 4 times I’ve played it. It drags on, and I dislike how little luck is involved, and how other players can just stomp all over my little engine of growth. As an engine-building player, I like games where I can build up my own little economy, as I do with something like Terraforming Mars. I have strong negative feelings about this game - too many rules to keep track of, and too much area control/offensive strategy for me. As a more passive player, I hate how other players can ruin my little engine. I don’t dislike this as much as Mansions of Madness, and I can see how people enjoy it. But it’s not for me, and please don’t make me play it again!

If someone expected to make mech-war and military expansions here will be very disappointed. I have no idea how this game could be rated in TOP10 games on BGG.

My initial reaction to the game was very favorable, and I rated it a 9. The art is cool, the quality of the components is very good, and turns are fairly short.

After a few more plays I have cooled on the game, hard. The game length is one huge factor, I just don't enjoy 3 hour games that much anymore, especially when you can be essentially locked out of the game for significant portions of it. This is the game for kids who think that Pizza with Spaghetti and fries is the best meal ever. A convoluted concoction with ideas grabbed from success stories like Settlers, Dune, Eclipse, put into a big mess but no consideration for making the theme work with the systems. Historical wargame complexity without the justification, or the game of Azad without the reality to back it up. Differentiation of sides by which terrain type they can cross a river into? This is hilarious nonsense trying to create complexity out of lack of inspiration, reflected at every level, from the pseudo-East European theme stuffed with mechs and then leaders with monster animals as familiars to the incoherence of the victory concepts of the game (the Quick start card for new players helpfully points out "find six things in which you can be good" and "learn the ten ways in which you can place stars"). All of this is design style eating itself.

The initial piddling of doing things to upgrade so that you can do more things takes on a significant part of the game executed differently depending on experience. Lesser experienced players seem to be drawn by the groupthink of playing a big game. "We're having fun right?" "We're doing things." A game with experienced players is filled with endless declarations of "I'm taking my turn now!" "Okay, are you done?" These desultory actions blend wonder and impatience beautifully often amplified or slowed by tempo disrupting event cards depending on group demeanor. Blowing away the player board chaff moves the game towards its finality. We're drowning in stars! The apropos tightening of tension in those final hours asks whether you value winning or ending. In a way, Scythe continues to play to its strength by allowing groups to make of it what they want.

Most of the game seems to boil down to your player board and how many actions you can perform during the game, and this giant map, full of resources and minis, either takes a backseat, or feels convoluted in execution. As a result, for all the thematic and interactive potential in Scythe, cube rails games actually deliver more of each.

My first game of Scythe was bitter, dull, and slow. I had realized I totally missed the rules about crossing rivers and freely crossed them. On a second play I found the game much better. The constrained options in the beginning of the game really help zip things along and make a big difference in pushing your faction towards what makes it unique which I enjoyed more than I thought I would. Despite others saying that combat is rare, I found that my faction was perfectly suited towards a combat-heavy strategy and quickly found myself completely ignoring any penalties for attacking because I was able to capitalize so much on the gains.

Scythe is essentially an engine-building game and kind of feels like a lighter, more streamlined version of Eclipse. It is less interesting than Eclipse in virtually every way but it is much, much faster and easy to teach as a result. While the core worker placement mechanism is, in my opinion, barely enough to keep you from falling asleep, the combat system and scoring both are pretty intriguing. Unfortunately combat isn't particularly weighty, so that really just leaves you with scoring, and thankfully the scoring is quite good. You can score in multiple dimensions and the values of each those dimension fluctuate from player-to-player based on track placement

So overall what do I think? Well... it's okay. The game is good, kind of boring and unexciting, but the pacing is brisk and it's easy to teach. I don't own any 4X style games in part because they are long and hard to teach, so this may be one I keep around for a bit. Although when I look on the shelf and see Le Havre, Troyes, and Brass - all games I find mechanically superior by a long shot - it's hard to look back and see a place for Scythe in my collection. I'll keep it for now and make another judgment later

Checklist – the board game! What is Scythe? A tableau builder? Yes! An area control game? Yes! An engine builder? Yes! A war game? Yes! A 4-X game? Yes! A majority game? Yes! A bluffing game? Yes! An asymmetrical game? Yes! A racing game? Yes! Scythe is simply everything! Or at least it seems that way.
In fact, it is a checklist: you tick off the individual to-dos one by one. Your own tableau determines the order in which improvements are unlocked, and the associated advantages determine the order in which the victory conditions are to be tackled. So you tick off one item after another until the game is over. Somewhere in between, in order to fulfill this victory condition, you fight one or two battles with your competitors, which are decided by the luck of the cards. So far, so sober—but in a striking, expensive presentation.

Scythe is definitely a well-designed game, although a bigger question would be if it was also fun. This is more ambiguous, I found. There are certainly fun parts, but the whole suffers from some critical drawbacks.

First (and this has been said repeatedly before), there are too many disincentives for combat. One of the places that Scythe succeeds over a game like Terra Mystica is that there is more direct opportunities for interaction, down to actual displacement and victory points via stars. However, you are punished for even initiating combat due to the popularity penalty (unless you have the Polish Camaraderie ability), forcing you to rely on the threat of combat, which is generally disadvantageous to both parties involved.

Second, the speed of the turns feels off for what is supposedly a 4X efficiency game. The rounds go quickly enough, with very little downtime, but the turns themselves are actually too short, giving you too little to do with too small of a result. I would have been happier with slightly meatier turns in exchange with slightly longer downtime.

Finally, the amount of interaction on the board, while direct, is almost arbitrary. Most of the game is played on your player mats, with the hex map and enlistment bonus technically providing interaction with only a few moments of actually engagement ever happening in the whole three hour game. Granted, these few moments are often highly important and exciting, but there's too little of it. Again, Scythe succeeds over Terra Mystica in this regard, but still fails compared to any number of 4X/efficiency games on the market.

Strong theme and art style wasted on mediocre gameplay. There is little to no exploration of strategy. Players who learn one strong strategy to use will constantly rely on it to win. Also, it's war-themed but also not a war game. Combining economics and area control works okay, I guess. But ultimately that means players can be led to think that it can be resource management and get loads of coins to win. Or maybe they can explore and spread out to control those Encounter cards, which are amazing on their own terms. Until they find out that it's basically just produce-enlist-mech-combat every game to win, and now they're upset and sad because their Encounter cards are meaningless and their workers are displaced. Meanwhile, the other players now have 5 stars on the chart. The actions are basic: move a dude or two, build something, deploy a mech, enlist. But somehow, they don't feel consequential enough. There's little to no sense of growth in your building or moving around. Mech and character are great toys, but that's just a default for crowdfunded games now. They add little to gameplay, much less than the thin cardboard pieces of other games that keep me entertained for hours. Scythe is a shallow game with a great superficial theme. I want to like it more, but right now, I think I only like looking at it. Playing it fills me with dread.

First this game tricks you into thinking it’s a hybrid area control game, when in fact the actual best strategy is a 90% solitaire efficiency puzzle. You only should be winning at most two fights and then stopping all aggression. I’m not a fan of non interactive games generally, but I am REALLY not a fan of how this game tricks you via art, minis, and even the box’s description.

And even if you know it’s really just a euro going in, there are problems with balance among the player board combinations, the skill gap between new players and the experts leaving new players feeling like they didn't really do anything, and the typical winning strategy of dogmatically following one long-term plan from the start by looking at your starting setup without ever really tactically adapting it as the game goes on. Nothing your opponents do or really anything that happens in the game actually matters besides your starting boards and starting position. If you both want to win and understand the basics of the gameplay, there is no actual strategic exploration in this game at all. Your strategy each game is practically scripted from the start. The 4X label is complete bogus.

After a few games, you'll quickly realize that each game is very plodding and samey with a lot of bloat that makes the game look both more complex and more sandboxy than it really is. Scythe's replayability is similarly incredibly superficial and in practice not really there. It just LOOKS like it has all of those things.

I had very high expectations when playing this game, but it felt short for me on various fronts:

-Short turns: the two actions one could undertake every turn are very short, and there is no room to expand them. With a board that demands multiple players, this can make the game drag on very long if someone needs to think.

-Little content: The 8 actions the player could undertake have very little impact on the game, and the options DECREASE over time once you do all 4 action per secondary action. There is no epic grand spectacle in the late game the player could work towards.

-Poor combat: There is quiet a bit of content to support combat, but its so heavily discouraged due to the loss of popularity one could gain from it. Popularity is a major key to victory, and the benefits from attacking players are limited in comparison.

-Limited Art: The art (direction) is great, and a major reason for players (including myself) to purchase the game. However, most of the art is hidden on cards the player has little interaction with, so you can rarely enjoy it.

Overall, the game does not have the eurogame in-game growth like a Wingspan or a Paladins of the Western kingdom, while at the same time lacking the dynamic combat (tricks) and balance of Inis. Just like Great Western Trail the gameplay lays an emphasis on turn efficiency rather than heavy engine building, but as previously mentioned, it strongly lacks interesting late game options that GWS thrives with.

Played once, not super impressed. Very messy, scattershot, unfocussed design - tons of levers to pull, but in practice extremely constrained choices. An odd mix of an efficiency design with a point salad aesthetic - a ton of tracks and different ways to score points, but an economic development engine that forces you to specialize.

This style of unfocussed design really doesn't do a lot for me. I had just played 504 the previous night, world 468 (Military, Roads, Production). The general feel of the game is actually kind of similar - a sort-of wargame where the main activity is actually building up your infrastructure - but because 504 is such a focussed design, it routinely gives you interesting and important choices and it feels way more engaging. And to be clear, this game (468) was actually not good. Before this I've played at least a dozen different 504 games and they've all been interesting. This was the first one I've played that clearly had some issues, mainly just that it went *much* too long in the face of players flailing with the objectives (games with Military really want to be fairly short). But even so, to me it was much more consistently interesting than Scythe. I'd actually rather play most of the "modern", more interesting Risk variants (Star Wars, Star Trek, Halo) than Scythe. Now in fairness, Scythe is really not intended to be a wargame - it's really a development game with a combat system bolted on that seems to have been designed to be as uninteresting as possible. If the game had any sense it would have stuck to its development theme instead tacking on a half-assed combat system. But it still has a lot of the same feel as a king-of-the-hill wargame.

Having said all this, I think Scythe is decent for what it is. If you like Feld games and 4X games, you'll probably find something here to like; it works, it's not terrible. I just find this sort of kitchen-sink design unappealing.

Scythe just doesn't click for me. I guess it has to do with the part that it is a euro game - action economy optimizer that presents itself as an epic area control warfare with giant robots.

In my experience the game of Scythe goes like this - players sit in different corners of the map, slowly expanding and doing the "euro stuff" - collect resourses, spend resourses, optimise your production. Then suddenly someone (can be multiple players) bulds his critical mass, does their moderately explosive last turn - and the game is over. Over the course of this 3 hours game (epic warfare with robots, I remind you) you as a group had like 5 fights combined.

Don't get me wrong — I get why people love Scythe. The actual "euro" part and setting are very interesting and engaging. It is just that disconnect between the impression that the game has and the actual gameplay I can't personally get over with.

This was a great introductory game to medium euros when I first played it, but after a couple dozen plays as well as reading various strategy discussions and perusing match statistics, it's only reinforced my opinion of it as a game that doesn't quite work mechanically. Clearly the aesthetics and art are very appealing to many (myself included) which heavily influences its rating, the same way the theme of Terraforming Mars inflates that game's rating.

The balance of Scythe is fairly disappointing. There are now 2 faction/mat combos that are considered unambiguously overpowered that somehow were missed in playtesting. Additionally, from what statistics have been gathered, there are still clear tiers for other faction/mat combos. It should be obvious that certain mats synergize much more effectively with some factions than others, which is a major downside to not having a modular setup. Players could potentially bid for factions, but bidding should be a last resort for balance, as it needlessly front-loads decisions and suffers when score distributions are difficult to read due to outsized effects of hidden information and player decisions.

The balance of encounters ranges from mostly useless to incredibly useful, and the game does not put enough luck mitigation to sort out the difference. Perhaps most egregious are the objective cards that can be trivially simple to complete or require you to move the world. This is made worse by not having them adjusted for player count, which heavily affects their balance. Saxony's effectiveness varies wildly on the encounter cards they receive.

I do really like the area control mechanic where workers are carried around and dropped off by the mechs. I love how you can cleverly use the workers as shields and punish overly aggressive players with popularity drops. I feel like a game could really make clever use out of those mechanics. Unfortunately, Scythe isn't that game. It's not necessarily a bad game (despite my overall negative tone), but it's the only hobby game I own that I have no interest in revisiting. I can't imagine ever wanting to play Scythe when I could play Gaia Project instead, for instance. Gaia Project is a master class of design in dealing with asymmetric faction balance and mixing economic elements with a spatial board. Scythe just doesn't cut it when stacked against other such euros.

A game that is, at once, both showered in praise and a not inconsiderable amount of criticism, my reactions to Scythe are mixed. I've cooled to it in subsequent years as I've refined my tastes a bit more. Where it may fail to do any one thing exceedingly well, it does quite a few things passably well. The whole, then, is potentially satisfying experience for omni-gamers without strong genre preferences, but may disappoint those looking for a more complete Euro-style game or a more complete combative area control game. Scythe does a bit of both, but a lot of neither.

The game is also wrapped in lovely artwork and components. It's "overproduced" in every meaningful sense, but seems to stay focused on evoking the game's setting rather than trying to wow us merely with the spectacle of the components.

I personally want more chaos and contention in my games these days, as well as more streamlined rules, fewer upkeep steps and micro-actions at every step. I acknowledge that Scythe is filling an area control niche for many who don't need or want more combative elements in such profound quantities. But it's ultimately too heads-down for me. And too long for the experience it delivers, with too much rules overhead. The game is played optimizing your action economy and upgrades on your players board. Too much focus spent there, too little on the shared central board and other players.

UPDATE SEPT 2022: 

4 stars to 2 stars. Here's why: High player count is the best way to play in order to muddy up the decisions tree by mid- to late-game, yet the pace is so boring at high player count even if everyone play at a nice pace.

I had some thoughts about this and reconfirmed this conclusion: it's a medium weight game with light weight decisions. This is annoying as your turn-by-turn decisions are so small and so incremental that you can plan 2 or 3 turn aways on what you want to do, yet you are still waiting for your turn. Decisions need to be big enough to warrant this.

My advice: just play the app. Having 4 - 6 AI players playing at lightning speed will spoil you forever. The app was a big factor on reducing the score.

This is a shame because I thought Scythe still is an exception to the usual trash that the publisher releases. My thoughts from July 2022 are still valid. It has long longevity, especially when expansions are added. But I think I am now on the tail end of this game. hence the 2 star. All that is left is to master every faction + board combo, and I'm not sure if I'm interested.

UPDATE JULY 2022:

Increased from 3 to 4 stars. The game has very long longevity, despite the scripted early game. The expansions also put more life into it which increases the number of plays before I get tired of it. The strategic "look ahead" in this game is just very good.

Easily one of the best optimisation Euro. But you need the expansions.

==================

UPDATE Dec 2020:

Still great. I think this is one of the better optimisation Euros out in the market. The frontload decision-making on Turn 1 is excellent.

Problems persists and the solitaire game is just too much drag, if played with newbies. Strategic openness wasn't as open as I wanted it to be, as the game is dictated by your faction + player board combo. Which means that there's little room for growth unless expansions allow wider strategy choices to compete against experienced opponents.

The static map is still okay, but I'm now hoping that the modular boards would increase the replayability and strategic openness.

UPDATE Aug 2020:

Played it with the mindset that it's a light Euro game and it works well. The game is about optimising your every action (and secondary action) and each action should be about building up either your future actions or VPs/popularity. No space to waste time or opportunity.

I can see why I didnt liked it back then. It's a shit 4x/area control game, if you approach it as a 4x/area control game. But it works well as a light Euro.

Still has the same inherent problems as before. Scripted early games with the static map and the same river crossing ability. Combat is inherently kingmaking, especially on an optimisation Euro that can rewards 2/3's of your game based on combat. But, again, the game is solely rested on its engine building core and it works fine.

The player boards are ultimately restricted that it doesnt give the same wide selection of strategy like other deep mid weight Euros like Concordia or even Nusfjord. Ergo, the game lacks legs in the long run. But thats for the future. For now, Im giving it a good rating of 7/10.

Scythe was the first game I backed on KS. Looking at the box, the art, the little mechs – how could I restrain myself?! I was so eager to play – I got it out whenever I had the chance and taught it to anyone I could convince to play.

And, yet, I kept finding myself thinking abrupt-ending after abrupt-ending – is that it? Once, I asked a friend who won, “So, at the end, you just put as many of your workers on hexes as possible?” “Yep!” That didn’t sit right with me but I continued to play and found the game to be more efficiency puzzle than clever strategizing.

Sure, I like the pace of the game – there’s rarely down time except if a battle takes place and even these are pretty exciting. But the actions that move things along so quickly are rarely interesting beyond perhaps the way a mech threatens a choke point.

Scythe is a great looking game that is a huge winner for Euro fans who like to convert resources into other resources, but I find it dull, all bluster and no substance.

Le gameplay est beaucoup trop scripté.
La chronologie des actions sera toujours la même, peu importe le semblant d’asymétrie que l'auteur essaye de nous faire croire au travers des différentes factions ou plateaux d'actions uniques.
Pour être dans la course, vous êtes contraint de faire d'abord des cartes rencontres qui sont surpuissantes, puis ensuite vous devez libérer des cylindres de votre plateau joueur (ces cylindres s'appellent des recrues, je crois... triste tentative de donner un thème à ce bout de bois). Les avantages octroyé par ces cylindres dépendent des actions de nos voisins : autrement dit, vos voisins vont vous faire gagner de très nombreux bonus, sans que vous ne fassiez aucun choix. Où est l'intérêt ludique ? On parle ici d'une quantité de points de renommé qui peuvent très nettement vous faire gagner la partie... Comment un jeu de gestion moderne peut reposer sur le fait que vos voisins vont faire votre victoire tout le long de la partie, sans qu'ils n'aient le choix de faire autrement. C'est l'invention du kingmaking, non pas sur une seule action, mais sur toute une partie !


La résolution des combats est nulle. Simplement nulle.
La preuve par les faits : un joueur à refusé de dépenser des points de combat parce qu'il se savait perdant d'avance. Alors l'autre joueur engagé dans le conflit a décidé de n'en dépenser aucun non plus... Résultat : la balance sur la piste militaire n'a pas bougé d'un iota, le gagnant n'a donc dépensé aucune ressource pour gagner ce conflit et accomplir un objectif déterminant pour la fin de partie. Même un jeu avec des règles aussi faibles que celles de Risk mets des ressources militaires en péril quand il y a un conflit à résoudre. C'est le minimum pour qu'un jeu devienne intéressant.
Là, c'est le néant.

J'ajouterai que les améliorations durant lesquels vous déplacez un malheureux cube d'une ligne vers une autre ont quelque chose d'insipide.

La gestion des ressources de base est très répétitive. Par ailleurs le jeu est contradictoire sur un point : il vous incite à regrouper vos ouvriers sur la carte pour produire efficacement en cours de partie, mais en fin de partie, il vous incite à étaler vos ouvriers sur la carte pour marquer un maximum de points. On pourrait croire que c'est ingénieux. Pour moi, c'est une grossière erreur de conception.

I get that this game is well-liked and has good reviews, but I thought it was meh for a couple of reasons.

First off, the backstory and art--nations engaged in active warfare with one another using huge mechs--screams mech wargame... but this game is kind of a hybrid between a war game and a resource management game with a focus on the latter. The theme is confused in my opinion.

The second point ties into the first in that it tries to do two things ending up in a bland mix of both. Resource management fiends won't be happy because their shrewd usage of turns can be disrupted and does not necessarily reward them as much as it should.

Likewise, warfare can only yield you two stars unless you play a specific faction and your victories matter little in the end because victory conditions are measured in control, gold, and other things which then get put together as money... the faction with the most money winds in the end. Here's my counterargument, though. Would it really matter if one country has a great economy when the other nation could steamroll them by the end? Sure, they could use their great wealth to enable their warmachine, but--so far--that is not what they have. Meanwhile, the other player has spent their time and resources already building up their capacity for war. In a wargame, they could take on the other player who is ill prepared to fight.

Like I said, I am confused as to what this game is trying to do. I feel like it would be better if the characters and tokens you move aren't gruff-looking alt-history soldiers and mechs meant for war, but instead space ships colonizing planets to see whose empire thrives. The gameplay seems much more reflective of such a scenario, anyway.
I see the appeal, just not my cup of tea!

You like giant mechs? You like gritty alternate history worlds where farming fields and waging war go hand in hand? You like carving out your faction’s destiny in the icy lands of 1920s Europa, all while eyeing the secrets of a mysterious Factory? Here is Scythe! A 1–5 player engine-building strategy game where you lead one of five unique factions, each with their own starting resources, location, and secret goal.

How do you win? By earning the most wealth and glory through expansion, combat, popularity, and progress before your rivals can. You’ll harvest resources, recruit villagers, build structures, and unleash hulking mechs to secure territory and intimidate your opponents. But here’s the twist there’s no player elimination, so you’ll always be in the fight, even if someone else rolls up with war machines at your doorstep. Gameplay runs smooth and fast thanks to Scythe’s action-selection system no waiting around for long rounds or phases. Every turn feels like momentum: upgrading your abilities to become more efficient, building your engine to snowball power, and choosing how your faction grows. Do you focus on military dominance? Economic might? Political popularity? Or a balanced mix that keeps everyone guessing? Encounters with the people of Europa give you choices help them, exploit them, or something in between shaping your path forward and adding just enough unpredictability to keep every game fresh. Combat isn’t luck-driven either; it’s all about outthinking your opponent and managing your resources wisely.

In the end, Scythe is about building something that feels like yours: an evolving faction engine, growing stronger every turn, racing against rival nations. Will your empire rise from the ashes of war to dominate Europa… or will your people be crushed beneath the treads of someone else’s mechs?

It's probably illogical, but I feel a bit weird playing a game that I know has, in theory, a lot of solvable problems. The fact that there is an objective best way to handle most things, and the fact that you could calculate it with just a little bit of effort, can make it extremely frustrating. Still, I think it takes a good few plays to squeeze all the juice out of it and get into that pseudo-solved space.

Anecdotally, my groups were a lot more prone to fighting than many people's experience, which probably made it more fun early on. And I respect the design philosophy of turning combat into a high-stakes experience that both sides are hesitant to enter, but it's pretty annoying when the game disincentivizes combat to this degree.

I really wanted to like this game, since I love territory war games and development games, and this games is a combination of both. Unfortunately, even though the game is great mechanically, I have two main drawback that prevent me from wanting to play more.

First, my main drawback is that the games feels like a multiplayer solitaire, which is something that I really dislike in games (of course, it's very personal). This feeling is the same that I had with Ark Nova, where I expected some interactions but in fact everybody is only looking at his own board, and the interaction is minimal. Here, it's even more disappointing, as I expected a lot of interaction from a war game, but here I feel like everybody will only do the minimal number of wars possible and focus on his own area.

My second drawback is that I feel like the strategy is straightforward depending on where you start, and you only do what the game expects you to do. For example, I started the game at the left, where a river was blocking the path. My first X turns were therefore only focusing on deploying a mech to traverse rivers, and the strategy was therefore already written for me. Therefore, I also feel like the game can be repetitive if you play it a lot, and the game is probably already "resolved", with some pre defined set of actions that are the best depending on where you start.

An interesting, surprisingly light Euro-Ameritrash hybrid. I say "surprisingly" because, despite all the bells and whistles in that huge box, the game at its core is a pretty simple area control game with some neat, easy-to-understand scoring mechanisms. I love that you can score points for doing all sorts of things, making combat only one small part of the gameplay. In this regard, the game reminds me of Eclipse: apart from some small skirmishes, players generally spend the game diversifying as they gear up for the aggressive endgame.

If I had one complaint, it's that the goals are a little too easy to get, and are mostly fulfilled by all players the end of the game. So, by the end most people will have built all of their mechs. Most people will max out their workers, etc.

I wish there were more ways to specialize (i.e. to score more points within a particular strategy), and thus vary your strategy from game to game: so, a "mech strategy" would incentivize going heavy into mechs early, and then provide more ways to score with them. A "worker strategy" would do the same within that track. As it is, each play of this feels kind of "samey."

Initial Impressions: If this is a 4X game as it was sometimes advertised as it is missing many of the 4X elements, and if it isn't a 4X game it is a good but far from amazing Euro.

The game seems more about completing objectives and managing resources so that you can always pay for the bottom action when you do the top one too (with a little bit of timing in case of opponent interference). Some of the ways to get stars also feel not really thematically tied at all (e.g. you have military power, but don't spend it). Therefore, it doesn't give the civilization building feel at all, and while there are upgrades they don't feel like you are learning new technologies, as they only make your other actions better.

It obviously lacks explore since the map is static and nothing is hidden, and its exterminate aspect while somewhat present is really weak. Combat is more a threat than something that actually happens frequently (in my game there were only 2 combats, and while I could see some play styles that would cause it to happen more frequently it still seems amassing troops is more as a deterrent). That you only have 1-5 combat units on the board at a time doesn't help with making combat more nuanced. I also don't like secret bidding especially for combat.

The poor combat also hurts the expand aspect, as while you can get a lot of points for expanding the lack of constantly jockeying for territory makes the expand less interesting.

The game also seems like it would be fairly samey in the beginning of each game, in that despite the different factions/action boards/objectives/you can go for different ways to achieve stars each game, they overall feel of what you do is still similar.

The encounter cards just don't feel that thematic. The story behind each one feels too disjointed from the rest of what you are doing, and so while they have flavor art and text that makes sense with the setting they just feel like random resource bonuses.

As for why I rate Terra Mystica so much higher, to be honest maybe I was too caught up in the hype of it. I don't remember my play of it enough to have a good gauge of it is actually my type of game. If I do like Terra Mystica more, I think it is due to the balance of being near opponents so you pay less for settlements vs. being far enough away that you have space to build (whereas here it seems like you basically always want your workers far away from opponents, and mech relatively close), you can build more, the factions feel more different, and that while there isn't movement it feels like you can affect the land more by terraforming.

Despite all the things I mentioned I dislike about this game, I did enjoy it and feel that the relatively simple action selection turns tied to chaining of these actions, along with the added logistics of the spatial map was cool. It just wasn't super innovative or anything deserving the hype, the artwork, or its ranking, and so it left me really disappointed.

EDIT: I've enjoyed this more on repeated play. All the issues I mentioned above I still have issues with, but they bother me less. I can enjoy it as an abstract action efficiency game with some confrontation that doesn't get too in your face, and I love my maps. Usually in a confrontation you will only start one if you are definitely going to win or going to tank it, so losing a bunch of combat resource while still losing doesn't happen too often, even if it feels terrible. I also always like games with player controlled endings. I can see the opening moves being scripted for experienced players, but I think the game still has enough legs for some exploration of each a couple times per player before you figure that out (assuming you don't read up on it online beforehand).

EDIT 2: nevermind, back down to a 6.

While I could play with casuals who don't know the meta game either, it irks me to know that winning/losing can be influenced by random asymmetrical starting positions. Did I win because I was good at the game, or did I just get an easy combo? Did I lose because I could have played better, or was my combo just weak? Even if the imbalances aren't that big in casual play, for me it just ruins the whole idea of rewarding skill expression, and will make me question whether any future victories or losses are actually deserved.

Scythe is an interesting mix of a bunch of different mechanics, but ultimately you're trying to upgrade your action efficiency in order to race to 6 points faster than your opponents. There's a ton of variability in what order you acquire these stars, and I like that there's both a faction board and an action board that changes every time. Personally I actually really enjoyed the "cold war" style interaction, where the threat of being attacked looms over you the whole game, while actual conflict is few and far between. I find that quite unique and enjoyable, and it's refreshing to have in what's mostly an efficiency game. The theme is also fresh and done very well here.

I will say I find it to feel a little samey from game to game. Although the variability seems extremely high, I don't find that much really feels different. Like we're all doing the same things in slightly different orders, and hoping we don't get attacked, and that's kind of it.

I will definitely continue to explore this one, but there's nothing here that I find particularly exciting compared to other interactive Euro's. I'd rather play something in the Terra Mystica family. I see why this made waves when it came out, but for me it's just a good game, with a refreshing interactive layer, but nothing amazing.

Overall - 8/10
Scythe has a weird way of being intimidating at first, easy and super fun once you get the hang of it, and then a bit dull as you improve and figure out the optimal sequence of moves for the first 6-8 turns. The game is a blast when everyone is new and trying to figure things out together, but if the players have varying skill levels, it can be a bore as everyone sits around waiting for the "good" player to execute their perfect sequence of moves and end the game before the rest have even gotten started.

There's just enough randomness to keep things interesting from one game to the next, but good/experienced players will crush poor/inexperienced players every time; unfortunately, the game is too heavy/long to expect a casual group to improve quickly enough to make for competitive games.

Scythe – A game that looks like war but plays like finely tuned engine-building art. Behind its stunning alternate-history visuals — dieselpunk mechs trudging through misty farmlands — lies a deeply strategic Eurogame about resource management, optimization, and careful planning. You’ll expand territories, produce goods, and upgrade actions, all while keeping an eye on your neighbors and their imposing metal beasts. Combat exists, but it’s more a threat than a focus — deterrence through diesel. It’s sleek, smart, and endlessly satisfying, with a table presence that turns heads and gameplay that rewards precision over aggression. Scythe proves that sometimes, the biggest weapon is a well-oiled economy.
It may not be a pure 4x war game, but i love resource management games and a little bit of skirmish so I do enjoy a lot this euro cold war simulator.

I came late to Scythe, in part because I took Paul's review at Shut Up and Sit Down at face value.

My tastes often align with SU&SD. It's acceptable to be wrong. No one is infallible.

Paul was wrong, even to the extent that I think he completely misrepresented this game.

I love Inis and Concordia too. I'm pretty sure I can find space on my shelf and at my table for those and Scythe.

Mechanically, it develops much of the elegance of "Eclipse" (2011) and takes it much farther in a cleaner system (which is an achievement).

The win conditions and combat system are excellent. The fact that Scythe is decidedly not 4x was an outstanding design choice regarding scope.

Also, the only way to characterize movement as "plodding" is not to understand how it works.

Sorry, Paul: love you, but sometimes you have to take your licks.

Finally, Scythe has an excellent rulebook, and you can learn 90% of what you need to know from the two-sided rules reference broadsheet. Read that first, and the rules are a breeze. That was surprising for a game that has this much depth.

I really like Scythe. When I first encountered it I was drawn in by the art and production, but was hesitant about what at first glance looked to be a combat focused game. Instead, I was delighted to find the focus was much more on generating resources, building up a production engine and expanding out across the map.

I like the slow build up of the game, from having just a couple of workers hanging around home base at the start, to slowly get out that first mech, then before you know it there's more mechs and buildings and you're out exploring the other side of the map.

And although the combat still doesn't excite me, I do kinda like that's there's not that much of it but instead an interesting tension of potential conflict that runs throughout much of the game.

The best from Jamie Stegmier. Scythe has climbed up my top 100 every year. A perfect example of why I play board games. The more I play it the more I enjoy it. The art is the best in boardgaming and explodes the immersive experience. The table presence is top tier. We love the 32 encounter card expansion pack. It's such an inexpensive way to make the game deeper. We have Wind Gambit, Fenris, and Invaders From Afar. We play it exclusively at the 2p count and we love it! Stonemeier games are always in print and that's good for the board gaming community and why they're our favorite publisher. We love the engine building that happens on your player mat and racing for area control before the game ends. The different civilisations are well balanced and creative. After over 20 plays , and many teaches , Scythe is reaching iconic status for us and just keeps on giving that original excitement! My #6 game of all-time and game of the year from 2016 , and it's not even close. So much beautiful boardgaming to enjoy here , its difficult to describe it all.

This really is a brilliant game, which is NOT a war game. It combines resources, dudes on a map, and your own board development with some asymmetrical abilities to create a lovely strategy experience. The multitude of different ways you can gain stars makes each game different, and end game targeting quite open.

The combat is minimal, unless you want to attack a lot, with winning a combat giving you a victory star (maximum two per player) of 6 stars to finish the game, but also being detrimental to you in loss of power and possibly popularity (arguably the most important thing in the game). This balancing act is genius as a mechanism.

Get to 6 stars and the game ends (unless you're playing an expansion) but then you all add up points (euro style) and there's every chance the player who triggered the end might not win.

I love scythe and only complain I don't get to play it more and the set up time, which is way less than gloom heaven but far more than monopoly.

(2018) Scythe stands in a class of its own. The design combines familiar mechanics (e.g. action selection, area control, card combat) in unique ways that set the game apart from the crowd. The much-loved and celebrated art work lives up to the hype and it is complemented by rather lavish production choices. Scythe is not a war game and it doesn’t fit neatly into any extant genre of Euro. It is rule heavy- not suitable as an introduction to board games or even as an intro to the heavier end of board games. Still, though it’s a lot to digest, that lot is all quite good.

(2024) I won’t lower Scythe’s perfect ‘10’, but I will note that after 5 years in the rotation it started to feel scripted. My last few plays have felt a bit stale, even when including some of the more bonkers expansion factions. Still- it took a long time to get here.

Great game in a spectacular and unique setting, high tension in a tough engine building game with elements of area control, conflict, worker placement, victory run, asymmetric and so on. The artwork is phenomenal!

Great Game.

You control one of 5 factions. You try to build the best society by achieving different objectives (building, combat, other things).

Each turn you select one of 5 spaces on your board (the 5th is only available after you've traveled to the center of the board). Each space has 2 possible actions you can take. Won't be able to take them all, as you won't have the resources to do it.

So you control territory, manage production, build mechs, have encounters, manage your military power, manage your popularity, etc....

I've painted the miniatures.
